speaker: A
text: Do you disagree? Am I not the Lloyd Blankfeim of Crypto in 2022?

speaker: B
text: Hey all, this is an interview I did with Kyle Davies, co founder of the bankrupt crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, which imploded in June of 2022 owing its creditors over $3 billion. Back in 2012, Kyle and his co founder Su Zhu, who were high school and college buddies, started three AC as an arbitrage shop, turning $1 million into anywhere from what they claimed was $5 billion to $10 billion at three acs height. In fact, key to its success was that grayscale bitcoin trust arbitrage trade, creating shares of GBTC and then selling them after a six month lockup period since GBTC traded over the counter at a hefty premium compared to its Nav, which was based on the price of bitcoin. However, when that premium switched to a discount in early 2021, suddenly three AC would lose money on that trade. Then May 2022 saw the crash of Terra Luna, into which three AC had invested $200 million, with their holdings of Luna hitting half a billion dollars at their peak. At that time, lenders tried to recall some of their loans to three ac. When the firm could not either repay the loans or post more collateral. Some of its lenders went under, such as Voyager, which had lent three ac $654,000,000.03. Arrows Capital was one of the major dominoes in the crypto carnage of 2022, and Kyle and Sue became emblems of an era of excess and irrational exuberance in crypto, as well as disliked figures for what the liquidators said was a lack of cooperation. A few weeks ago, Kyle reached out to me wanting to do an interview. I was surprised given his history, but welcomed the opportunity to ask him some questions about the past couple years. I was dealing with a lot of health issues that week, and so ungrateful to Kyle that he was willing to push our interview from our initially scheduled time and with that, now onto the show. Hi everyone. Welcome to Unchained, your no hype resource for all things crypto. I'm your host, host Laura Shin, author of the Cryptopians. I started covering crypto eight years ago and as the senior editor, Forbes was the first mainstream media reporter to cover cryptocurrency full time. This is the March 19, 2024 episode of Unchained. Polkadot is the original and leading layer zero blockchain with over 2000 plus developers, and the Polkadot 2.0 upgrade will be a massive accelerator for the ecosystem, making it faster, more secure and adaptable. Perfect for Gamefi and Defi to build, grow and scale. Join the community at hey Unchained listeners. As you know, it's hard keeping up with the fast paced world of crypto, so we've got just the thing for you. Subscribe to our free unchained daily newsletter at unchainedcrypto dot substack.com. you'll get the latest crypto news and original articles from our reporters, as well as summaries of other happenings and bullet points, plus our meme of the day, all curated and written by our amazing team. It's still your no hype resource for all things crypto, just in newsletter form. Sign up at unchainedcrypto dot substack.com. again, the URL is unchained crypto dot substack.com dot.

speaker: B
text: Financing today's guest is Kyle Davies, advisor to Oxfund and co founder of the now bankrupt Three Arrows Capital. Welcome, Kyle.

speaker: A
text: Hey Laura.

speaker: B
text: Thanks for having me on your crypto hedge fund. Three Arrows capital collapsed in June 2022, and you haven't been cooperative with Teneo, which is in charge of liquidating three AC's assets. You then launched and closed a crypto bankruptcy claims exchange, OpenX. You launched three AC Ventures, which now appears to be defunct or at least has a non working website. And recently you became the advisor to Oxfun. When I asked on X what I should ask you, a large number of people expressed dislike of you or disapproval with how you've conducted yourself since the collapse of three AC so why do you continue to try to work in crypto?

speaker: A
text: I mean, Laura, you had some loaded intro there, right? Do you think we should address some of those? Yeah, like, okay, so I had a meeting with Teno like two weeks ago. The idea that we are not in contact or not cooperating with them is posturing. We absolutely have, we hadn't, we just had a, we just had a meeting with them. We also have meetings with creditors all the time, by the way, and I met with DCG last week. Number of investors, or creditors are also investors in Oxfund, and some of them have made quite a bit of money from that too, by the way. So to give a couple names like Bitcoin magazine, that's David Bailey and Tyler Evans. They've done very well on this and have been long time supporters. They are both creditors of three AC, they're both and investors and Aux, the token Oxfun. So we've tried to reach out to as many people as we can. We have been in contact, we have made offers to the estate, both to help, but also to get a piece in a new business. Those will be ongoing and I do expect like some sort of settlement at some point. In addition to that, there are a number of creditors that just choose to participate in the estate, and we're very thankful that they, they have, and I think they've also done very well by it. So he's been quite mutual in that sense.

speaker: B
text: And so you say that you are cooperating with ten AO, but they say that your lack of cooperation and also Suzhou's lack of cooperation has cost them tens of millions of dollars in additional fees and legal expenses for the three ac estate. And then, as you know, in Singapore.

speaker: A
text: It'S, it's a liquidator's job to say that the founders are not cooperating. That's like, it is their job to say such a thing because the whole point, the way, I mean, I had to learn a lot, unfortunately, about liquidations this past year. But basically the way they work is they're trying to maximize value for these states, right? And they do so by various means, like they can do various pr, they can pressure people in various ways, and the whole point is to get a good settlement for the estate. So I think that they're doing a reasonable job. But the idea that what they say is very accurate about us is malarkey. It just doesn't make any sense. If they felt that way, then maybe they should have told me on the last call, because we do a regular call, we had a call with them a couple weeks ago. So, yeah, I suspect when there is a settlement, there will be favorable savings on all sides. But until then, I'm sure you're aware of, the media just amplifies what they, you know, what they hear, and people use that to. For their own means. And a liquidator's job is to get maximized value for the state. So that's exactly what they're doing. We don't fault them for it. We help where we can. But, I mean, if they feel the need to do this to get a better settlement, so be it. That's their prerogative.

speaker: B
text: In September, on a visit to Singapore, your co founder Suzhou was arrested and sentenced to four months in prison for not cooperating with the liquidators. You also were sentenced to four months in prison in Singapore for the same charge. So how do you explain that?

speaker: A
text: Well, that one's very easy to explain. We were actually very surprised when we heard that. I got a call, I remember I got a call from our lawyer saying that sue had just been picked up at the airport, and we were like, we don't know why yet. But then we figured it out. It was because there was a court date, which we didn't know about. Obviously, if we had intended not to go to the court date, you just wouldn't be in Singapore. Right, but sue was in Singapore, and given that there is a court date, you would go, because otherwise you'd be in contempt of court. Right. And as it turns out, there was the court date. He did not know about it. He then got picked up at the airport, and then he got a pretty surprising sentence. Usually for this kind of thing, we would have. I found out later that you expect, like, a week or two, and then you go to court, because the whole point is, you know, this is not your sentencing, per se. This is like, you're supposed to do an examination. Right. And so either way, sue ended up getting four months. He ended up serving six, and then another period of time at home. He then did his examination, and that was that. So, yeah, obviously, I don't plan on going back soon, because if they remove the contempt, then, yeah, sure, I'll happily do an examination, but if they're not going to do that, then obviously not. So for them. I think we were all pretty surprised by that. Sue definitely was very vocal about it afterwards. Did you see some of his content that he did?

speaker: B
text: I did.

speaker: A
text: It was it. I mean, I did not know what to expect. And the whole time that he was there, I was, like, very nervous. Thinking like, oh, poor sue. Like, what it, what is happening to him? I've seen the movies, I've seen this, but I don't know if I know anyone personally who's ever gone to jail before. And the way he expressed it was quite different. Right? Like, he talked about meditation, he talked about helping. He's considering writing a book with one of his cellmates to help other people that have certain, you know, that go through a similar process. Very, very interesting. He actually really took the best of it, given that it had to happen, but no one wants to go, but given that it did, pretty impressive. So, yeah, so that's where we are.

speaker: B
text: And just to clarify, I think you misspoke. You said it was a four month sentence, but he served six. I believe he served two in prison and then two under house arrest.

speaker: A
text: Six weeks.

speaker: B
text: Six weeks.

speaker: A
text: He did six. So it was twelve weeks total, of which he did, I think, six weeks in prison. Oh, sorry. It was 16 weeks. 16 weeks would have been the full. But in Singapore, they're pretty forgiving, apparently, about this. And so you're allowed to knock off a third and then split half home, half there, something on that order, but basically admitted him. Six there, and then another period.

speaker: B
text: Okay, and why did you not know about the court date, if you say that you are in close contact with the liquidators?

speaker: A
text: Well, it's kind of our lawyer's job to tell us about this kind of stuff, because there's so many emails flying around that it's really not my full time job to pay attention to this. No one's paying me. This is not my job. I have lots of other things that I do, but this is very much a duty, per se, that we would like to do, and that is very helpful. And if we can maximize value, we can. And, yeah, the long and short of it is, I don't know, our lawyers didn't tell us, so if they did, maybe we would have.

speaker: B
text: You fired your lawyers?

speaker: A
text: We totally didn't. Maybe we should. I don't know, it kind of just, for me, like liquidation. So I've learned, is a long process. It's like a potentially even ten year process. Some of these go even more than ten years. So this is not something that you do as a full time job, and there isn't something to do every day, but it is something that kind of runs in the background and you kind of need to read up on it every once in a while and be like, okay, yeah, this thing's coming up, or, oh, this meeting's happening, or, oh, this asset sale is happening or whatever. They need advice on this, and then you do it. Right, but it's not something you think about on a daily basis that would. It's just not the way it is.

speaker: B
text: Well, I would imagine that this is quite possibly the biggest event to ever happen in your life, so I'm a bit surprised to hear you act as if it's just kind of a small matter that you're not paying much attention to.

speaker: A
text: The bankruptcy was. That was for sure. There was the first major, major failure we had had, and that was a very big one. But the liquidation is. It's a ten year process. It's not like if I were to do this full time, that'd be like a whole legal team's worth of work. I'd be reading like, 100 page affidavits all day long, and that is just nothing. That's why people hire lawyers for us. We are definitely involved in certain things, but I just am not proficient in the esoteric. Whatever day to day of what's happening, we do a lot of other stuff too. We're spending a lot of time on aux fun and trying to get that going. There were a bunch of big updates today, maybe I can mention later, but basically there's a lot of stuff that we do. We have to rely on people. And then this one somehow slipped through. So sue had meditate for six weeks or so.

speaker: B
text: When you say that typically for this kind of infraction, the sentence is not this long. Why do you think it was so long?

speaker: A
text: I have no idea. Yeah. I mean, I wasn't there. I have no idea. But basically, like, missing a court date is what he did. Right. And so you would. So, for example, it actually was a bit of a problem that he was in jail for six weeks.

speaker: B
text: A problem for.

speaker: A
text: It was a problem for the liquidator, because they wanted to examine him, and they couldn't. They had to wait six weeks. And so actually, that is why it was a little bit surprised. Like you would think, okay, maybe just like, give him a week off, and then he goes back or something like that. But that's not the way it works. He has to be there for the whole period of time, and the communication apparently is really not great. He spoke about that in some of his videos that he recorded. But there's a messaging system where someone puts, you have to add a contact, and then the contact has to be approved, and then the message comes in. We can only get a certain amount of messages, and each one of those has to be approved, and the long and short of it is you just have very little contact with the outside world. So you just. Including your lawyer, by the way, you just don't know what's going on. And so, yeah, the examination that did take place happened well after his time in jail, and then he had a time to prepare, and then they had to set a date. And so this set the liquidator back probably three months, my guess, which was probably not great. Right. You can imagine a better process.

speaker: B
text: So you said that you've been in touch with the liquidators just in the last few weeks. What was discussed at that time certainly can't say.

speaker: A
text: It is a confidential, closed door kind of a meeting. That's the way all liquidation meetings basically are.

speaker: B
text: All right. Well, you also hinted that now, because of this warrant for your arrest, or rather the prison sentence, that you do not plan to go back to Singapore. But you are a citizen of Singapore, so what are your plans for where you're going to go or where you're going to live?

speaker: A
text: Well, no, no, I'm not going to go back immediately, but obviously, these things just resolve at some point. There are settlements. These are common kinds of tactics. So I've learned where people try to pressure for this, pressure for that settlement or whatever, but in the end of the day, all these things resolve. I hadn't been through a liquidation before. I don't know if you have, but if you haven't, then you're just not aware of how these games play out. But suffice to say, I can tell you I'm reasonably confident in a ten year period, the whole estate will resolve, I hope much faster than that, because that's very painful for creditors to have to wait that period of time to date, for example, there's been still no distribution to creditors, which is unfortunate, because it's a big crypto rally, and there's a high opportunity on cost of capital. Liquidation processes are like that. They take a long, long period of time, and that was one of the big lessons that we learned right away. Like, if there were many things that I would have done differently and would have done wonders for us, but also for creditors above and beyond what is happening now. But the reality is we just don't have a choice. It isn't full liquidation. It is up to the liquidator. They will run their own process now.

speaker: B
text: And so you were born an american citizen, and prior to the collapse of three AC, you became a singaporean citizen and renounced your citizenship here in the US. But, you know, I imagine your family of origin is in the US. Do you believe that if you came to the US, you would be arrested?

speaker: A
text: Nope, should be fine in the US. There's no actions against the US.

speaker: B
text: And have you come to the US since the collapse of three AC?

speaker: A
text: I have not, but I see no reason why I can.

speaker: B
text: You were living in Dubai after the collapse, and the government there ended up levying fines against you, you know, for.

speaker: A
text: Something very different, by the way.

speaker: B
text: Okay, so do you want to talk about that? What happened there?

speaker: A
text: Oh, yeah, yeah, sure. So, no, after the collapse, actually, we had. The only regulatory action that we had against us was in Singapore, actually, and it was not related to the collapse at all. It was due to like a regular. Like a regular filing that you have to do, updating particulars or whatever. That was six, eight months prior, and basically they did a notice on that. I think also our Eum was too high. We had way too much money, which was a product of crypto. That is one of the problems. You just make too much money too quickly. But also we were regulated as a smaller fund. We were applying for larger licenses, and it took some time, and that was part of the reason we wanted to move to Dubai, too, because it was easier. We had an MoU with the regulator there. We would have been able to run a bigger fund there, and we were a multi, multi billion dollar fund at that point, so that would have made a lot of sense. But basically, when we went down, the Dubai regulator said, we're not involved in this at all. They haven't. And the Singapore regulator said, we're going to do a notice about them and say that they can't run a fund here for the next nine years. But no fines, nothing else. That's literally all that happened on the regulatory front. And then separate from that, there was another company that was set up that was run by Mark Lamb, and Leslie Lam was the CEO. It's called Openx. We were advisors as well of that. Pretty innovative idea. We were looking through the bankruptcy process and seeing that things could be done differently. And there were ways that you could make more fungible, tokenized kind of claims and try to get people liquidity faster and maybe better value. Turns out that didn't really work out very well. It was just hard to get everyone aligned in the same vision. The concept of a claims exchange was a good one. We told one of our friends, he actually built it, and he is the number one claims exchange for FTX claims right now. So I have no doubt that it just turns out it's a very small business that's the other thing. We had ambitions to be the next FTX, FTX 2.0, be a big crypto exchange. And from what I can see, the guys that are doing bankruptcy claims are very niche. It's only claims, it's a couple of estates and not like high volumes, I guess, in the sense of FTX. I recorded an episode with Thomas Brazil yesterday, who's an expert gen someday if you haven't. He really gets this. And he said, I think it was like two and a half billion of volume or something like that that he had seen in FTX claims pretty big, but still, if you compare, the crypto volume is not huge. So we had bigger ambitions, didn't really work out, and decided that Oxfun would be the future with.

speaker: B
text: Yeah, we'll talk about both of those later. But going back to your location, you were living in Dubai after you have this arrest out of in Singapore. So where are you now? You told New York magazine you were in Portugal.

speaker: A
text: I'm in Europe.

speaker: B
text: And are you still in Portugal, which is what you told New York magazine.

speaker: A
text: I'm not going to tell you exactly where I am, but I bounced around between Europe and Asia, basically.

speaker: B
text: Why do you not reveal your location?

speaker: A
text: You can imagine why they would be problematic, Laura. So I think it's just for people that need to know they do. But for the general audience, I mean, it's just not.

speaker: B
text: And when you said I could imagine why, like, can you spell out specifically what your concerns are?

speaker: A
text: Well, like, anyone in crypto, frankly, should be careful about their location. All people should be careful about that. Right. And in my particular case, like, if there are people that want to, you know, play games or whatever, it just makes sense not to do that. So for me, I've tried to be as public as I can, try to help people in the estate as much as I can, try to get investors into our, into Oxfod and other things where they can make some money and some have. But I am not a. Yeah, I'm really not like running around, you know, meeting people on the street or things like that. Sue, by the way, I mean, we do do conferences. Sue is going to be speaking, he's keynoting in Hong Kong soon, and he's got a headline panel in Dubai for token 2049. So we are very public. You can find us, but on a day to day basis, I value my privacy.

speaker: B
text: And those appearances are in person, not virtual.

speaker: A
text: Yep, both of them. There will be panels, there will be keynotes.

speaker: B
text: And what about you? Because you do have this worn out for your or this prison sentence in Singapore. You know, he's already served.

speaker: A
text: That's in Singapore, right? So I'm not going to keynote in Singapore, but I could keynote anywhere else in the world, pretty much.

speaker: B
text: Okay. So obviously, 2022 was a big year for crypto in the sense that there were a number of failures, and we've begun seeing the legal repercussions of those failures. Sam Pink, Ben Fried of FTX is facing sentencing at the end of the month. Do Kwan, the creator of Terra Luna, was arrested. Montenegro and both the US and Korea are trying to extradite him. CZ, the former Ceober finance. I didn't mention Barry Silbert, but we could throw that one in there. You know, I mean, there's a number of these and, you know, as for three ac, Bloomberg reported that the SEC and CFTC were investigating whether you and sue misled investors and whether or not you should have registered with the agencies. And in a Twitter spaces last summer, you said, quote, we never misrepresented, nor did we borrow from individuals past any point of insolvency. If we did, there would be major repercussions. By the way, there are nothing. Why are there not? There are not for a reason, because we did not. Is it still your stance today that the lack of any formal legal action against you is proof that you did not make any misrepresentations?

speaker: A
text: I mean, we didn't, but it's now been new update. It's now been almost two years and also still not. So, by the way, the CFTC and the SEC, I don't believe, have contacted us at all. So furthermore, they're like in the US, which is irrelevant to an offshore fund. So, no, we haven't been contacted. No, we haven't been investigated. The regulatory bodies that have, I mentioned them earlier what they did, which is in Dubai. Nothing. And in Singapore, a notice based on something that was a filing that was done a year prior or something. So, no, we haven't. No, we don't expect it, but if we did, then we would address it. I just don't see it as a major concern for us. There are so many other things that are important and we're focused on them. But, yeah, I mean, if we can focus on recoveries or whatever, then we'll do it.

speaker: B
text: So in the final days before three acs insolvency, you and sue sent messages to various firms and individuals asking them to lend you bitcoin against GBTC that you would pledge as collateral. On June 10, there was a message that said, quote, all you have to do is lend us BTC and we'll do the rest. 100 BTC would net around 120. Just four days later, sue tweeted, quote, we are in the process of communicating with relevant parties and fully committed to working this out. And then two days after that, three AC was insolvent. So describe to us what you were trying to do in those final days.

speaker: A
text: Well, first of all, we didn't take any money for the GBTC idea, but the idea was what Genesis usually did. The pitch that Genesis would give us is we can lend BTC to you, we can subscribe into the Grayscale trust. And then at the time, I was trading at a premium. We can sell it and we can give you the difference, or vice versa. If it's trading at a discount, you can buy the discount, try to scalp it or whatever. We were very active in this trade. I think we're probably the largest firm, if nothing one of the largest firms doing the grayscale trade. For viewers background, there are two major firms involved in this. There is Genesis, the OTC lender, and then there is grayscale, which is a trust now, an ETF. And the market's done very well by that. But at the time, it was just a trust where you could subscribe but you could not redeem. That created this dynamic where it could trade at a premium or it could trade at a discount. And you can imagine there are trades that you can do on either side of that. But basically we participated in those. And those are all under one group, by the way, that's the DCG group. They're the largest creditor in the three ac estate because we were the largest user of their products. And yeah, it was something along those lines. But frankly, we didn't really like, I don't know if I, we didn't execute any of those. So, I mean, if we were to able to do more business, maybe we would be still alive. But, yeah, we did not. The market was pretty bad at that.

speaker: B
text: Blockchain.com has said that during that time, Unsu, this is in May 2022, Unsu sent them a letter saying that three C had nearly $2.4 billion under management. And now the firm's lane, Castleman and the liquidators believe that this overstated the fund's assets. Castleman told New York magazine, quote, we firmly believe they committed fraud. There's no other way to state it. That's fraud. They lied. What do you have to say to that?

speaker: A
text: Prove it. We didn't do it. Like, if we did, there would be problems, but I don't see any problems here. Right. So the reality is we always represented what we believe to be the best estimate of our nav. Due diligence was always done as per. Like, what would make sense at that time? I mean, if you, you could imagine really, really strict due diligence, right. Third party audits, things like that. But in crypto, that's not the way it was done at that time. So because of that, we tried to come up with estimates. These would be much faster. Instead of being six months delayed, they could be, like, we could try to make estimates more real time, but they would be much less accurate. And that was, we would give these from time to time. They were not on a regular basis at all. They were kind of on a bespoke basis, and we gave them out when we did. I mean, those are the navs that we believe. The navs were never finalized, by the way. The last nav of three arrows was, I believe, December 2021 or something like that. The later ones were never finalized. Yeah, like, I don't know if a lawyer thinks that they can calculate the Nav and they know what it is. Like, good for them, but that's not the way that. Like, that's not the way it works.

speaker: B
text: Castleman also told New York Mag that you were insolvent, but you were continuing to try to borrow, saying, quote, it became clear that they were insolvent but were continuing to borrow, which really just looks like a classic Ponzi scheme. Comparisons between them and Bernie Madoff are not far off. What do you have to say to that?

speaker: A
text: I say that that is classic posturing. That is exactly the kind of stuff that people try to do to get settlements. I suspect when we do settlements, all of their statements are going to be that we're wonderful people and we settled amicably. But this is exactly the kind of stuff that people do.

speaker: B
text: And I have to give credit to New York magazine. Jen Viechner is amazing, as you can tell. A number of these details came from her reporting. She did report that on the same day that sue had tweeted that you were communicating with the relevant parties and fully committed to working all this out. That three AC sent $32 million in stablecoins to a crypto wallet that belonged to an affiliated Cayman island shell company. The liquidators say that it's unclear where those funds went, but there is a theory that in the days up to three ACS collapse, because you and sue had reached out to every wealthy crypto whale, all the top executives and investors, and you did not receive money from any of them, that you eventually found lenders of last resort. This theory is that the money may have been used. This money, the $32 million that was transferred to this crypto wallet, may have been used to repay the mafia. What do you have to say to that allegation?

speaker: A
text: Jen is a very nice lady. I've spoken to her a number of times. She, in the same article, wrote that we lost a trillion dollars. She wrote that we borrowed from the mouth. And she wrote that I am weird because I speak fluent Japanese. And to that I would say bit racist. But I disagree. I think it's totally fine to, first of all, speak Japanese. It's a wonderful language, wonderful people. Second of all, I think we did not lose a trillion dollars. That would be, that'd be really impressive, actually, to lose a trillion dollars. I don't think anyone's ever lost a trillion dollars before. But no, we did not lose a trillion dollars. And thirdly, no, we did not borrow from the mob. So, yes, Jen has had a number of, she's done two articles. They're always very one sided. And I think it's fine. I mean, it gets people's interest out there. But, like, I mean, you have to be able to read more than one article. Right?

speaker: B
text: I can't believe that. Trillion dollars in the actual text. She doesn't say that. The headline, whoever wrote the headline used the word trillion in the headline, but that's not what the article says.

speaker: A
text: So she did very much go into being weird for set for studying Japanese and for borrowing from the mob, though. Right?

speaker: B
text: So you're saying we were this, that there was no loan that you took from the mob?

Like, it's a pretty core crypto belief, right? We happen to be pretty public because we were running a very big fund, but most people are not, right. And that I respect. So I don't know. It's like a core crypto belief that people should be able to have their anonymity if they want or be public if they want. It's a free speech, like, for open decentralization. Like, it's just a good crypto, you know, belief, and I support it. So, in terms of oxfun, it is a gamified derivatives platform. It's got a couple of innovative ideas. One of the ideas is provable solvency. So, for example, why did FTX or Luna or numerous other of the 2022 genre companies go down? It was because they were protecting a dollar peg. They had coin collateral, but they had dollar debts. And then when your coin collateral drops to a certain amount, you can't afford your dollar debts. All of a sudden, there's a bank run, and all of a sudden it spirals to zero. We try to design a. Something that was not that way, that what they use is coin collateral with coin P and L. Ox is the token. And that's one of the core kind of ideas. The other kind of idea is that it should just be fun, right? Like, so we have these competitions. We're doing a battle right now, me versus sue. Turns out we're both down money. So I am winning because I am down less. But, yeah, we thought it'd be fun to just show our positions. People don't have to even stake us. We charge no fees, by the way. But you don't have to stake us. There is a price pool. You can just look at the positions. If you want to trade them, go trade them. We just thought it was just a fun thing to do, and then we have some other staking ideas.

speaker: B
text: So if you don't charge fees, then how does it make money?

text: Oh, no, in our battle, we don't. The exchange itself does. Yes. It has traditional, like, transaction fees, which the exchange does not take, by the way. And you go back to stakers. So, of course, we call that prison locking. So if you go to prison voluntarily, you stake for a period of time, and you earn the trading fees of the exchange back. And while you're staking in prison, you actually get a staking token, which you can use as collateral to trade. And so your money's not, you know, your coin's not doing nothing. It's not only earning the fees, but also, you know, use has a utility to it. And that just went live today, by the way.

speaker: B
text: And why did you name that token prison?

People should go there on YouTube. It's called the Ox podcast. He really knew a lot, and they thought deeply together about how to reform certain ideas, what was good, what was bad, how to help people get through it.
